intro: Guillauminia calcairophila, commonly known as the desert bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family, characterized by its bell-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky soils and thrives in full sun, exhibiting a low, sprawling growth habit. Its flowers are usually blue or violet, with five petals, and bloom in the spring. Guillauminia calcairophila is adapted to withstand drought conditions, making it a resilient species in its native habitat.
